&lt;div class="sf_singlePost"&gt;
    &lt;p class="sf_back"&gt;
        &lt;a id="ctl00_MainContent_BlogPosts1_ctl00_ctl00_backToList1" href="../../../blogs.aspx"&gt;Go Back&lt;/a&gt;
    &lt;/p&gt;
    &lt;h1 class="sf_postTitle" style="float: left; width: 500px;"&gt;
        The Truth About Over-The-Counter Drugs
    &lt;/h1&gt;
    &lt;div class="socialHolder"&gt;
        &lt;iframe src="http://www.facebook.com/plugins/like.php?href=http%3a%2f%2fwww.whydrugrehab.com%2fblogs%2fview%2f13-07-25%2fThe_Truth_About_Over-The-Counter_Drugs.aspx&amp;layout=box_count&amp;show_faces=false&amp;width=60&amp;action=like&amp;font&amp;colorscheme=light&amp;height=65"scrolling="no" frameborder="0" style="border:none; overflow:hidden; allowTransparency="true" class="facebook-like-button"&gt;&lt;/iframe&gt;&lt;a href="http://twitter.com/share" class="twitter-share-button" data-url="http://www.whydrugrehab.com/blogs/view/13-07-25/The_Truth_About_Over-The-Counter_Drugs.aspx"data-count="vertical" data-via="RecoveryPlace"&gt;Tweet&lt;/a&gt;&lt;script type="text/javascript" src="http://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js"&gt;
    </script>
   </div>
   <p class="sf_postTags" style="float: left;">
   </p>
   <p class="sf_postAuthor">
    <a href="../../../blogs.aspx" id="ctl00_MainContent_BlogPosts1_ctl00_ctl00_postedBy">
    </a>
   </p>
   <p class="sf_postDate">
   </p>
   <div class="sf_postContent" id="ctl00_MainContent_BlogPosts1_ctl00_ctl00_pnlContent" style="float: left;
        padding-top: 20px;">
    <p>
     It was at the young age of 14 that Melanie Sawyer first began to abuse over-the-counter cough medicine. To Sawyer, an ordinary middle school girl, it was for a good time and something that took the edge off the angst of her teenage years. But as time progressed, Sawyers drug abuse became more serious as she moved from cough and cold tablets, which contain the drug Dextromethorphan (DXM) to a similar, but stronger high
     <a href="/addictive-drugs/hallucinogens/lsd.aspx" target="_blank">
      LSD
     </a>
     ,
     <a href="/addictive-drugs/hallucinogens/pcp.aspx" target="_blank">
      PCP
     </a>
     and
     <a href="/addictive-drugs/depressants/alcohol.aspx" target="_blank">
      Alcohol
     </a>
     .
    </p>
    <p>
     <br/>
    </p>
    <p>
     As her addiction escalated, Sawyers relationships with her family deteriorated. It even caused her to miss her sisters wedding after slipping into a coma from the abuse. Her
     <a href="http://www.therecoveryplace.net/treatment-programs/drug-rehabilitation/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">
      drug addiction
     </a>
     eventually led to homelessness and after a drug and alcohol fueled night arrested and sent to prison for 11 months.
    </p>
    <blockquote>
     More than 100,000 hospitalizations and 16,500 deaths a year are attributed to over-the-counter painkillers.
    </blockquote>
    <p>
     Bill McCarberg, MD, explains, Many Americans believe that if its an over-the-counter medication, someone (the Food and Drug Administration) has vetted it as safe and therefore, one pill is good but two is better. Unfortunately, this way of thinking has grown over the years showing a major increase in ER visits for over-the-counter medicines.
    </p>
    <p>
     A new report from the Drug Abuse Warning Network (DAWN) has discovered that ER visits related to the over-the-counter drug Zolpidem, also known as Ambien, have skyrocketed. According to the report there was a 220 percent increase of ER visits related to the drug from 2005 to 2010.
    </p>
    <p>
     The scary part is thinking about the mass amount of people that are unaware of the dangers, risks, and negative side effects that can come from abusing over-the-counter drugs. Some of these effects can include:
    </p>
    <p>
    </p>
    <ul>
     <li>
      Persistent sedation or intoxication due to overuse.
     </li>
     <li>
      Increasing functional impairment and other medical complications.
     </li>
     <li>
      Psychological manifestations such as irritability, apathy, anxiety, or depression.
     </li>
     <li>
      Adverse legal, economic, or social consequences.
     </li>
    </ul>
    <p>
     Over time, over-the-counter drugs can severely damage an individuals body and health, most commonly in the stomach. After the drugs have reached their peak damage on the stomach, they move to the cardiovascular system, then to the kidneys, and ultimately can lead to death.
    </p>
    <p>
     <br/>
    </p>
    <p>
     Furthermore, like Melanie Sawyers story, over-the-counter drugs can lead to experimentation with much more dangerous and
     <a href="/addictive-drugs.aspx" target="_blank">
      addictive drugs
     </a>
     . What started as harmless can and will stem into severe mental, emotional and physical consequencesaddiction.
    </p>
    <p>
     For more information on the dangers of over-the-counter drugs, or to seek help for an addiction, please dont hesitate to call us today.
    </p>
   </div>

   </p>
